evidence: This process “hardens” the beam-increasing its average energy.
Beam hardening artifacts occur when X-ray beams pass through an object, resulting in changes in beam energy distribution that affect image quality.
X-ray beams are polychromatic, meaning they contain photons of various energies, forming a spectrum.
Higher-energy photons are less easily blocked, the beam becomes more penetrating along longer paths.
Proper correction methods and models that account for beam hardening are necessary to reduce these artifacts and improve image quality.

triples.evidence: X-ray beams are polychromatic, meaning they contain photons of various energies, forming a spectrum.

concepts.term: many reconstruction algorithms assume a monochromatic beam, leading to errors.
